title: Iowa eminent domain bill would widen route for carbon pipelines - The Des Moines Register
description:
The Iowa Senate's top Republican is proposing a plan to widen the route in which pipeline projects can build as they attempt to secure land voluntarily for their projects, rather than resorting to eminent domain.
Senate Majority Leader Mike Klimesh, R-Spillville, said Tuesday, Jan. 20, that he would introduce two bills related to eminent domain.
text:
The Iowa Senate's top Republican is proposing a plan to widen the route in which pipeline projects can build as they attempt to secure land voluntarily for their projects, rather than resorting to eminent domain.

Senate Majority Leader Mike Klimesh, R-Spillville, said Tuesday, Jan. 20, that he would introduce two bills related to eminent domain.

title: Thailand introduces 1% SAF blending mandate from 1 January - Oils & Fats International
description:
Under the new rules, Jet A-1 fuel specifications and quality requirements at production and sales points had been classified into three categories: conventional Jet A-1; co-hydro-processing and conventional Jet A-1 blended with neat SAF, the 5 January report said.
The department also set specifications for SAF, requiring feedstocks and production to comply with ASTM D7566, with production limited at this stage to HEFA (hydro-processed esters and fatty acids).
Bangchak Corporation was building a SAF plant in Thailand using HEFA technology, with used cooking oil (UCO) as the main feedstock.
PTT Global Chemical (GC) was also producing SAF using co-processing HEFA technology from UCO, with an initial capacity of 16,438 litres/day (around 103 barrels/day).
The European Union (EU) had also imposed SAF blending requirements for flights departing EU airports, with a 2% blending mandate introduced last year, The Nation Thailand wrote.
text:
Under the new rules, Jet A-1 fuel specifications and quality requirements at production and sales points had been classified into three categories: conventional Jet A-1; co-hydro-processing and conventional Jet A-1 blended with neat SAF, the 5 January report said.

The department also set specifications for SAF, requiring feedstocks and production to comply with ASTM D7566, with production limited at this stage to HEFA (hydro-processed esters and fatty acids).

Sarawut Kaewtathip, director-general of the Department of Energy Business, was quoted as saying the regulations supported Thailand’s goals of carbon neutrality and net zero emissions and were aimed at ensuring SAF producers met international standards, in line with the government’s policy to promote sustainable and low-carbon aviation fuels.

In addition, the policy aligned with measures by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), which was pushing airlines worldwide to use SAF as a key mechanism for driving the aviation sector towards net zero, he added.

Bangchak Corporation was building a SAF plant in Thailand using HEFA technology, with used cooking oil (UCO) as the main feedstock. The facility had a capacity of 1M litres/day (about 6,289 barrels/day) and was expected to become operational in the second quarter of 2026, the report said.

PTT Global Chemical (GC) was also producing SAF using co-processing HEFA technology from UCO, with an initial capacity of 16,438 litres/day (around 103 barrels/day).

Sarawut said the two regulations marked Thailand’s initial phase of SAF adoption, which relied mainly on HEFA as alcohol-to-jet (AtJ) technology remained under development and was not fully commercialised.

The European Union (EU) had also imposed SAF blending requirements for flights departing EU airports, with a 2% blending mandate introduced last year, The Nation Thailand wrote.

title: Senate majority leader proposes pipeline bills | Iowa Public Radio
description:
Senate Majority Leader Mike Klimesh, R-Spillville, introduced a bill he said will mostly eliminate the need to use eminent domain for hazardous liquid pipelines, including carbon pipelines.
The bill would widen the corridor for a proposed pipeline route, giving companies more flexibility to go around landowners who aren’t willing to sell part of their land.
Klimesh said a pipeline company would have to prove it did everything possible to only use voluntary easements before asking state regulators for eminent domain powers.
He said the bill puts landowners in the driver’s seat, while ensuring carbon pipelines can help Iowa access markets for sustainable aviation fuel and enhanced oil recovery.
A leading opponent of carbon capture pipelines said the proposals do nothing to protect the rights of landowners who don’t want a pipeline on their land.
text:
Senate Majority Leader Mike Klimesh, R-Spillville, introduced a bill he said will mostly eliminate the need to use eminent domain for hazardous liquid pipelines, including carbon pipelines.

The bill would widen the corridor for a proposed pipeline route, giving companies more flexibility to go around landowners who aren’t willing to sell part of their land. Klimesh said a pipeline company would have to prove it did everything possible to only use voluntary easements before asking state regulators for eminent domain powers.

He said the bill puts landowners in the driver’s seat, while ensuring carbon pipelines can help Iowa access markets for sustainable aviation fuel and enhanced oil recovery.

“That would make Iowa farmers profitable again and have a huge impact on Iowa’s overall economic health,” Klimesh said. “Access to these markets is not optional for Iowa farmers and Iowa. It is a necessity.”

Klimesh also proposed a tax on carbon dioxide that flows through pipelines. A leading opponent of carbon capture pipelines said the proposals do nothing to protect the rights of landowners who don’t want a pipeline on their land.

title: Avianca Cuts Emissions 5.1% Despite Capacity Growth - Mexico Business News
description:
Colombian flag carrier Avianca reduced its total carbon emissions by 5.1% between 2019 and 2024, despite an 18.1% increase in overall capacity, according to data from EmeraldSky.
Additional initiatives outlined in Avianca’s 2024 sustainability report further supported emissions reductions.
Through its Avianca Fuel program, the airline implemented 24 fuel-saving initiatives in 2024 aimed at reducing fuel burn across its network.
Beyond flight operations, Avianca focused on reducing emissions from ground activities and infrastructure.
According to the sustainability report, Avianca’s emissions strategy also includes compliance with international market-based measures.
text:
Colombian flag carrier Avianca reduced its total carbon emissions by 5.1% between 2019 and 2024, despite an 18.1% increase in overall capacity, according to data from EmeraldSky. Over the same period, the airline cut its carbon intensity by nearly 20%, lowering emissions from 82.6 to 66.3 grams of CO₂ per available seat-kilometer.

The emissions reductions stem largely from fleet modernization. Since 2019, Avianca has retired nearly two-thirds of its Airbus A319 aircraft, phased out its entire A321 fleet, and exited regional jet and turboprop operations. These aircraft were replaced with a larger number of Airbus A320neo jets, which deliver approximately 20% fuel savings compared with previous-generation models, along with additional A320ceo aircraft. On long-haul routes, the airline replaced Airbus A330 aircraft with Boeing 787s, which offer lower fuel consumption per seat. As a result, the average aircraft size in Avianca’s fleet increased from 144 seats in 2019 to 181 seats in 2024.

Avianca also reconfigured cabins across both its narrowbody and widebody fleets to improve seating density and fuel efficiency. Although global supply chain constraints pushed the average fleet age to about 9.5 years, the airline reconfigured 24 aircraft in 2024 alone, bringing the total number of optimized aircraft in operation to 141. These reconfigurations reduced emissions per revenue passenger-kilometer by 15.35% compared with non-reconfigured aircraft.

Additional initiatives outlined in Avianca’s 2024 sustainability report further supported emissions reductions. Through its Avianca Fuel program, the airline implemented 24 fuel-saving initiatives in 2024 aimed at reducing fuel burn across its network. These included expanded use of single-engine taxi operations, with compliance rates reaching 84.38% in Bogota, 98.76% in Quito and 77.17% in El Salvador. The airline also introduced new decision-support tools for dispatchers to improve fuel planning and coordinated fuel-reduction strategies with flight standards, operations engineering and maintenance teams.

Operational efficiency programs targeting pilots and flight dispatchers also contributed to emissions cuts. In 2024, the initiative involved 1,926 pilots and 128 dispatchers and used incentives to encourage the application of manufacturer-approved fuel efficiency practices within strict safety parameters. Top-performing pilots were recognized quarterly, alongside additional incentives to reinforce adoption. Together, these actions helped avoid 64,520 tons of CO₂ emissions in 2024, including 62,042 tons from passenger operations and 2,480 tons from cargo activities.

Beyond flight operations, Avianca focused on reducing emissions from ground activities and infrastructure. In 2024, the airline added 14 electric vehicles for maintenance operations in Bogota and Rionegro, replacing combustion vehicles and reducing emissions by up to 80% per vehicle. At its Rionegro maintenance facilities, Avianca also promoted bicycle use for internal transportation, logging 1,449 trips that avoided an estimated 2,006 kilograms of CO₂. Infrastructure investments included the generation of 816,896 kilowatt-hours of solar energy in 2024, supplying 34% of the electricity consumed at the Rionegro facility. Cargo warehouses in Rionegro and Miami operate with energy-efficient lighting systems and refrigeration technology with zero ozone depletion potential.

According to the sustainability report, Avianca’s emissions strategy also includes compliance with international market-based measures. The airline reported emissions from international flights under the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) for seven operating airlines within the group, with each report verified by an accredited independent body in accordance with ICAO standards. In parallel, Avianca prepared for the European Union’s ReFuelEU Aviation initiative, which takes effect in 2025 and requires airlines to monitor fuel use, comply with anti-tankering rules and progressively increase the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). During 2024, the airline strengthened fuel-consumption monitoring at European airports, automated reporting processes and secured agreements with SAF suppliers to meet regulatory requirements on routes from Europe.

SAF remains a central pillar of Avianca’s long-term decarbonization strategy, although the airline acknowledges significant technological, regulatory and financial barriers to large-scale deployment in Latin America. In 2023 and 2024, Avianca participated in technical working groups led by Colombia’s civil aviation authority to develop a national SAF roadmap under the “Cielos limpios: Aviación para la vida” initiative. If approved, the roadmap would position Colombia as the third country in the region, after Chile and Brazil, to adopt a formal SAF strategy. Avianca is also engaging with fuel suppliers, government agencies, universities and industry partners to explore Colombia’s potential as a SAF producer and exporter, while evaluating mechanisms such as Book and Claim to support early adoption.

title: Ethanol Emerges as Key Market Solution for Corn - RFD-TV
authors: Marion Kirkpatrick, RFD-TV News Staff, www.rfdtv.com, marion-kirkpatrick, rfd-tv-news-staff
description:
The Nebraska Farm Bureau (NEFB) President, Mark McHargue tells RFD NEWS he is in talks with officials across the pond to capitalize on demand for U.S. ethanol.
“All of our ethanol plants are major ethanol plants.
“About 40% of our corn exports go to Mexico, and about 40% of our ethanol exports go to Canada,” Swanson said.
“So collectively thinking about corn and ethanol, important markets.
And these were already important markets before USMCA, but they have grown in importance and market share since then.
text:
NASHVILLE, TENN. (RFD NEWS) — Farmers across the country are looking for ways to market a glut of corn right now and tackle business planning for the growing season ahead. The Nebraska Farm Bureau (NEFB) President, Mark McHargue tells RFD NEWS he is in talks with officials across the pond to capitalize on demand for U.S. ethanol.

“In Nebraska, we do have a carbon pipeline now that’s functioning and running,” McHargue explains. “All of our ethanol plants are major ethanol plants. Can produce ethanol at a very, very low carbon score, and that’s important primarily to our export markets. I had a conversation with leadership from the UK while I was at the [AFBF] Convention. They’re still very excited about potentially buying SAF [Sustainable Aviation Fuel] from this country, upping their ethanol usage, and they certainly still want that low-carbon fuel.”

Next door in Iowa, Secretary of Agriculture Mike Naig tells RFD NEWS grain producers in his state are also hoping to see ethanol come to the rescue. Naig told RFD NEWS that year-round sales of E15 would be the ideal market for many growers in his state.

“I know they want to get this done, and the wheels of Congress just broadly have been so slowly grinding,” Naig said in a recent interview with RFD NEWS. “We need to move some things that are important. Look, timing’s everything. Let’s use this most recent crop report as maybe the final signal that we need to push this thing through, because it actually can have a dramatic impact, both for the farm community — and look, in Iowa, where Iowa consumers are saving $40,000,000 a year, just last year, in using E15 versus 10% ethanol blend.”

U.S. Auto Makers Push Back on Flex-Fuel Vehicle (FFVs) Production

Regular gasoline blends contain up to 10 percent ethanol, E15 uses 15 percent, and so on. On the other hand, FFVs can use ethanol blends up to 85 percent. While higher ethanol blends are available, most vehicles produced and sold in the U.S. cannot run on them. Markets analyst Chris Swift told RFD NEWS that U.S. manufacturers need to start adapting before it is too late.

“We really need our automobile manufacturers to be able to increase that engine or be able to warranty it to be able to handle that higher [blend],” Swift explains. “And we noticed that when we got into the flex fuel a couple of years ago, most of those vehicles now can’t be found anywhere. So, we really need the help of the automotive manufacturers to be able to increase that engine performance with that higher ethanol production.”

General Motors faced a class-action lawsuit in 2022 over those vehicles, with users claiming that the high-ethanol blend damaged their engines. That case was dismissed, but other parts of the suit are still working their way through the courts. However, the issue is not a matter of developing the technology. These FFVs are already produced by Chinese manufacturers like BYD and sold globally. However, Chinese EVs and FFVs are extremely rare in the United States due to steep tariffs, national security restrictions on connected vehicle tech, and a lack of established dealerships, making direct import complex and costly.

Expanding Domestic Ethanol Production

The ethanol industry is expected to expand this year. Broker Sherman Newlin tells RFD NEWS that when everything comes online, it could be positive news for corn growers.

“We’re supposed to be building out about another billion gallons worth of production, just plants expanding because of our tax credits that are available out there. And everybody’s trying to grind as much as they can. So, if all that could come online within the next year or so, or maybe a little bit longer than that, I mean, another billion gallons of ethanol produced could use up to another 300 million bushels of corn.”

Brazil’s ethanol industry is also expanding this year. Newlin says the South American trade giant currently operates about two dozen plants right now and could expand to as many as 40 within the next few years.

Corn Groups Push for Input Cost Reductions and USMCA

As farmers plan for the upcoming growing season, many are monitoring geopolitical factors and potential impacts on input and commodity prices. Lewis Williamson with HTS Commodities joined us on Tuesday’s Market Day Report to provide his market outlook.

In his interview with RFD NEWS, Williamson discussed what he is watching in today’s market during the first weeks of the year. He also shared his outlook for the upcoming growing season and the factors he anticipates influencing planting decisions and market conditions.

As row crop farmers prepare for spring planting, economists at the nation’s largest corn group, the National Corn Growers Association (NCGA), say it will be important to watch geopolitical developments, especially regarding fertilizer.

“It’s a relatively big chunk of the operating costs,” explains NCGA Chief Economist Krista Swanson in a recent interview with RFD NEWS. “It usually makes up about 35% of operating costs. And, you know, it’s kind of the most volatile of the input costs. And so even some small swings and fertilizer prices can have big implications for farm profitability, which is a big deal when we are in this profitability string that we’re in right now, where costs have been higher than prices the last few years.”

Fertilizer prices are a mixed bag lately. Analysts at DTN found that five of the eight major types had become more expensive recently, while DAP and MAP both fell by less than 10 percent. All eight types are more expensive than this time last year, with UAN 32 up 27 percent year over year.

NGCA is also paying close attention to recent comments on the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), the trade pact that President Trump called “irrelevant.” Swanson says they will be pushing to keep that agreement in place.

“About 40% of our corn exports go to Mexico, and about 40% of our ethanol exports go to Canada,” Swanson said. “So collectively thinking about corn and ethanol, important markets. And these were already important markets before USMCA, but they have grown in importance and market share since then. So, I think that speaks to the testament of the importance of this.”

USMCA is set for review this summer, but recent comments from President Trump are now calling that into question. In addition to calling it “irrelevant,” he claims that Canada gets more out of the agreement than America does. If the review is not successful this summer, the trade pact could sunset in 2036.

title: The next cause of airfare price spikes isn't even in your plane yet - The Sydney Morning Herald
description:
Travellers face paying more for renewable airline fuel than they are willing to as governments overseas push the sector to reduce its emissions.
The average traveller, meanwhile, is willing to contribute a mere $2.60 extra toward sustainable fuel for a long-haul flight.
Sustainable airline fuel, a lower-emission alternative derived from sources like used cooking oil and green waste, is essential for decarbonising air travel but is currently three to six times more expensive than conventional jet fuel.
The expected price pressure comes as the aviation industry is still recovering from COVID-19 lockdowns, which decimated airline skilled staffing, crippled supply chains and pushed up airfares.
Australia has no binding sustainable fuel blend mandate and no large-scale production facilities, although it is considering incentives to spur the industry.
text:
Travellers face paying more for renewable airline fuel than they are willing to as governments overseas push the sector to reduce its emissions. The trend marks a renewed threat to affordability after the pandemic jacked up ticket prices.

A peer-reviewed study by researchers at the University of Sydney found that the additional cost to long-haul flight from using sustainable aviation fuel ranges for $68 to “hundreds of dollars” per ticket.

The average traveller, meanwhile, is willing to contribute a mere $2.60 extra toward sustainable fuel for a long-haul flight.

While households baulk at costlier travel, governments in Europe are implementing decarbonisation mandates that will force airlines to adopt sustainable fuels, even though the scarcity of the low-emissions fuel will create an added cost for the industry.

Sustainable airline fuel, a lower-emission alternative derived from sources like used cooking oil and green waste, is essential for decarbonising air travel but is currently three to six times more expensive than conventional jet fuel.

“Australian and New Zealand travellers like the idea of sustainability, but they are not willing to foot the bill for [sustainable fuel],” said Rico Merkert, professor of transportation at the University of Sydney.

“If government and industry don’t collaborate, I think flying will become more expensive,” he warned.

The expected price pressure comes as the aviation industry is still recovering from COVID-19 lockdowns, which decimated airline skilled staffing, crippled supply chains and pushed up airfares.

According to an Australian Competition and Consumer Commission report from December 2025, domestic airfares had already reached their highest levels in years due to “strong demand … which puts upward pressure on airfares.”

Yet government fuel mandates are advancing, even as the capacity for the industry to produce the fuel remains deeply constrained.

The EU requires a mix of sustainable fuel to be blended with traditional fuel, starting at 2 per cent in 2025, rising to 6 per cent in 2030, 34 per cent in 2040, and 70 per cent by 2050, according to Sydney-based NoviqTech, which creates software to track emissions.

The UK requires 2 per cent in 2025 and 10 per cent by 2030.

Australia has no binding sustainable fuel blend mandate and no large-scale production facilities, although it is considering incentives to spur the industry.

Industry group Airlines for Australia and New Zealand CEO Stephen Beckett said the aviation sector wants to lower environmental impact and is aware of the risk for consumers.

“If you simply jack up the price of jet fuel, on top of all the other fees and charges being levied on airfares, the cost of doing business is going to go up,” he said.

“We need to make sure aviation remains affordable for all Australians.

“We want to decarbonise and need to get the policy architecture right, so the demand and supply-side policy work together, and not against each other.”

Despite the rapid growth of electric cars, battery or hydrogen-powered aircraft are not likely to make a significant contribution to reducing emissions from planes before 2050, according to industry group A4ANZ, making sustainable fuel crucial despite its cost.

Loading

SAF comprised only an estimated 0.6 per cent of total jet fuel consumption in 2025, the International Air Transportation Association said in December.

It is on track to rise to 0.8 per cent this year.

At current price levels, the cost of SAF translated into an additional US$3.6 billion ($5.4 billion) in global fuel costs for airlines last year. Airlines spent $US236 billion on fuel last year.

In December, IATA’s director general, Willie Walsh, said: “If the goal of sustainable fuel mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park [succeeded wildly].

“But if the objective is to increase SAF production to further the decarbonisation of aviation, then they need to learn from failure and work with the airline industry to design incentives that will work,” he said.

The University of Sydney researchers queried 1001 consumers on what they were willing to pay for a more “green” flight, and found that SAF was “a very hard sell”.

“SAF did not resonate with most travellers,” the researchers said.

title: Advanced Biofuels Market Size, Share & Growth Report 2033
description:

Advanced Biofuels Market Key Players: Some of the Advanced Biofuels Market Companies are:
text:
Advanced Biofuels Market Report Scope & Overview:

The Advanced Biofuels Market size was valued at USD 17.82 Billion in 2025 and is projected to reach USD 42.27 Billion by 2035, growing at a CAGR of 9.06% during 2026-2035.

The Advanced Biofuels Market is growing due to increasing global demand for sustainable and low-carbon energy alternatives. Government policies and mandates promoting renewable fuels, rising fuel prices, and stricter environmental regulations are driving adoption. Technological advancements in feedstock conversion, such as lignocellulosic biomass, algae, and waste oils, are enhancing production efficiency. Growing investments in biojet fuel, renewable diesel, and biobutanol, along with the push for decarbonization in transportation and aviation, are further accelerating market growth worldwide.

Market Size and Forecast:

Market Size in 2025 USD 17.82 Billion

Market Size by 2035 USD 42.27 Billion

CAGR of 9.06% From 2026 to 2035

Base Year 2025

Forecast Period 2026-2035

Historical Data 2022-2024

Advanced Biofuels Market Trends

Rising adoption of advanced biofuels driven by environmental concerns and global greenhouse gas reduction goals.

Increased government support through stringent regulations, renewable fuel mandates, and incentives for sustainable fuel production.

Technological advancements in feedstock conversion, including lignocellulosic biomass, algae, and waste oils, improving efficiency and scalability.

Rapid growth potential in emerging markets like Asia Pacific and Latin America due to energy demand, urbanization, and policy support.

Expansion of sustainable aviation fuels and circular economy practices, supported by industry collaborations and investment in next-generation biofuels.

The U.S. Advanced Biofuels Market size was valued at USD 4.77 Billion in 2025 and is projected to reach USD 10.87 Billion by 2035, growing at a CAGR of 8.63% during 2026-2035. The U.S. Advanced Biofuels Market is growing due to supportive government policies, renewable fuel mandates, rising demand for low-carbon transportation fuels, technological advancements in biofuel production, and increasing adoption of bioethanol, biodiesel, and renewable aviation fuels.

Advanced Biofuels Market Growth Drivers:

Environmental Concerns and Technological Advances Drive Global Advanced Biofuels Market Expansion Across Transportation and Industry Sectors

The growth of the global advanced biofuels market is primarily driven by increasing environmental concerns and the urgent need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Governments worldwide are implementing stringent regulations and renewable fuel mandates to curb carbon emissions from transportation and industrial sectors. Rising fuel prices and the volatility of fossil fuel markets are further motivating industries and consumers to adopt sustainable alternatives. Technological advancements in feedstock conversion, including lignocellulosic biomass, algae, and waste oils, have enhanced production efficiency and scalability, making advanced biofuels more cost-competitive. Additionally, the growing demand for bioethanol, biodiesel, biobutanol, and sustainable aviation fuels is propelling market expansion, particularly in regions like North America and Europe, where supportive policies and infrastructure facilitate widespread adoption.

Under the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS), the EPA set advanced biofuel blending requirements to increase from ~5.94 billion gallons in 2023 to ~6.54 billion gallons in 2024 and ~7.33 billion gallons in 2025, highlighting regulatory support for higher advanced biofuel use in transportation fuels

Advanced Biofuels Market Restraints:

Advanced Biofuels Market Growth Constrained by Feedstock Limits Conversion Complexity and Regulatory Challenges Globally

The global advanced biofuels market faces restraints due to feedstock availability and seasonal variability, which can limit consistent production. Complex and time-consuming conversion technologies, along with limited large-scale infrastructure for distribution and blending, hinder rapid adoption. Regulatory differences across countries and uncertainties in policy implementation can slow market growth. Additionally, competition from conventional fossil fuels and first-generation biofuels, as well as technical challenges in scaling next-generation fuels like algae-based biofuels and biojet, pose operational and logistical challenges for producers globally.

Advanced Biofuels Market Opportunities:

Emerging Markets Drive Advanced Biofuels Growth Unlocking High Potential Through Algae Biojet Fuel Innovation and Aviation Decarbonization Initiatives

Significant opportunities exist globally in emerging markets such as Asia Pacific and Latin America, where increasing energy demand, urbanization, and government incentives are accelerating the adoption of renewable fuels. Investment in research and development for next-generation biofuels, such as algae-based fuels and biojet fuel, presents high-growth potential. The aviation sector’s decarbonization initiatives and the push for circular economy practices, including the use of agricultural residues and waste oils, also offer substantial prospects for market players. Collaboration between technology providers, energy majors, and governments is expected to further expand production capacity and drive long-term growth in the global advanced biofuels market.

Australia announced a A$1.1 billion (≈ US$735 million) cleaner fuels programme to support low‑carbon liquid fuels including SAF and renewable diesel, with projects expected by 2029

Advanced Biofuels Market Segment Analysis

By Biofuel Type, Bioethanol dominated with 38.87% in 2025, and Biojet Fuel / Renewable Aviation Fuel is expected to grow at the fastest CAGR of 9.78% from 2026 to 2035.

By Feedstock, Lignocellulosic Biomass (e.g., agricultural residues, wood chips) dominated with 34.76% in 2025, and Algae is expected to grow at the fastest CAGR of 10.22% from 2026 to 2035.

By Application, Transportation (Road, Aviation, Marine) dominated with 53.12% in 2025, and it is expected to grow at the fastest CAGR of 9.39% from 2026 to 2035.

By End-User, Automotive Manufacturers & Fleet Operators dominated with 41.55% in 2025, Airlines & Aviation Companies is expected to grow at the fastest CAGR of 9.54% from 2026 to 2035.

By Biofuel Type, Bioethanol Dominates Advanced Biofuels While Biojet Fuel Soars Driving Aviation Decarbonization and Sustainable Travel Growth

In 2025, bioethanol remained the most widely used advanced biofuel due to its compatibility with existing vehicles and fuel infrastructure. The period from 2026 to 2035 is expected to see significant growth in biojet fuel and renewable aviation fuels, driven by global aviation decarbonization initiatives, airline commitments to sustainable fuels, and increased government support for cleaner air travel.

By Feedstock, Lignocellulosic Biomass Leads Feedstock Use While Algae-Based Biofuels Gain Momentum Driving Future Growth

Lignocellulosic biomass was the leading feedstock in 2025, sourced from agricultural residues and wood. From 2026 to 2035, algae-based feedstocks are expected to gain momentum due to their high yield potential, non-competition with food crops, and suitability for next-generation biofuels.

By Application, Transportation Sector Drives Advanced Biofuels Market Growth Boosting Emission Reduction and Sustainable Mobility Globally

Transportation, including road, aviation, and marine, dominated the market in 2025 as advanced biofuels were primarily used to reduce emissions in mobility sectors. Between 2026 and 2035, demand in these segments is projected to grow strongly, fueled by global decarbonization goals and regulatory mandates.

By End-User Industry, Airlines and Automotive Industries Lead Global Shift Toward Advanced Biofuels Driving Sustainable Transportation Growth

Automotive manufacturers and fleet operators were the primary consumers of advanced biofuels in 2025, driven by the push for greener fleets. From 2026 to 2035, airlines and aviation companies are expected to increasingly adopt sustainable fuels to meet environmental targets and reduce carbon footprints.

Advanced Biofuels Market Report Analysis

North America Advanced Biofuels Market Insights

In 2025, North America dominated the global advanced biofuels market with a 34.24% share, driven by supportive government policies, renewable fuel mandates, and well-established biofuel infrastructure. The region’s strong adoption of bioethanol, biodiesel, and renewable aviation fuels, particularly in the United States, has fueled market leadership. From 2026 onwards, continued investment in next-generation biofuels, sustainable aviation fuel production, and technological advancements in feedstock conversion are expected to further strengthen North America’s position as a key global market for advanced biofuels.

U.S. Advanced Biofuels Market Insights

In North America, the United States dominated the advanced biofuels market in 2025, driven by the Renewable Fuel Standard, extensive bioethanol and biodiesel production, government incentives, and well-established infrastructure supporting both transportation fuels and emerging sustainable aviation fuels.

Europe Advanced Biofuels Market Insights

In 2025, Europe accounted for 29.76% of the global advanced biofuels market, led by strong regulatory support, such as the EU Renewable Energy Directive, and increasing investments in sustainable fuels. Advanced biofuels like biodiesel, bioethanol, and biojet fuel are widely adopted to reduce carbon emissions in transportation and industrial sectors. From 2026 onwards, growing demand for cleaner fuels, expansion of bio-refineries, and government incentives are expected to drive continued growth across European countries.

Germany Advanced Biofuels Market Insights

In Europe, Germany dominated the advanced biofuels market in 2025, supported by strong government policies, extensive biodiesel and bioethanol production, advanced bio-refinery infrastructure, and initiatives promoting sustainable aviation fuels to reduce greenhouse gas emissions across the transportation and industrial sectors.

Asia Pacific Advanced Biofuels Market Insights

The Asia Pacific advanced biofuels market is expected to grow at the fastest CAGR of 9.94% from 2026 to 2035, driven by rising energy demand, rapid urbanization, and increasing focus on sustainable transportation. Countries like China, India, Japan, and Australia are investing heavily in bio-refineries, algae-based fuels, and renewable aviation fuels. Government incentives, supportive policies, and the need to reduce carbon emissions in transportation and industrial sectors are fueling market expansion, making Asia Pacific a high-growth region for advanced biofuels during this period.

China Advanced Biofuels Market Insights

In the Asia Pacific region, China dominated the advanced biofuels market, driven by strong government policies, large-scale bio-refinery projects, investments in algae-based fuels and sustainable aviation fuels, and initiatives to reduce carbon emissions in transportation and industrial sectors.

Latin America (LATAM) and Middle East & Africa (MEA) Advanced Biofuels Market Insights

In 2025, Latin America and the Middle East & Africa (MEA) are emerging markets for advanced biofuels, driven by increasing energy demand and government initiatives promoting renewable fuels. Brazil and Argentina lead LATAM with strong bioethanol, biodiesel, and renewable aviation fuel production, supported by abundant feedstocks. In MEA, early-stage adoption of biofuels is growing due to investments in renewable diesel and SAF projects. From 2026 to 2035, continued policy support, infrastructure development, and technological advancements are expected to accelerate market growth in both regions.

Competitive Landscape for Advanced Biofuels Market:

Neste Corporation is a global leader in renewable and sustainable fuels, specializing in advanced biofuels such as renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). The company focuses on converting waste, residues, and innovative feedstocks into low-carbon fuels, supporting decarbonization across transportation, aviation, and industrial sectors worldwide.

In May 2025, Neste began supplying sustainable aviation fuel to FedEx at Los Angeles International Airport, marking FedEx’s first major U.S. SAF deployment.

Chevron Corporation is a major U.S. energy company expanding into advanced biofuels through strategic acquisitions and renewable fuel production. It owns and operates multiple biorefineries via Chevron Renewable Energy Group, is developing renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel technologies, and partners with feedstock and catalyst developers to produce lower‑carbon fuels. Chevron’s efforts support broader decarbonization goals by integrating biofuel production into its global fuel distribution and refining network while reducing lifecycle emissions.

In November 2024, Chevron inaugurated the Ames Technology Center in Iowa to boost R&D in lower‑carbon fuels including biodiesel, renewable diesel, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), and renewable natural gas.
